concepts.concept_name: Understanding place value up to 10,000 (ones, tens, hundreds, thousands, ten thousands)
Reading and writing number names up to 10,000
Expanded form of numbers up to 10,000
Face value and place value of digits in a number

in_scope: Numbers up to 10,000 (five digits including 10,000)
Place value chart: ones, tens, hundreds, thousands, ten thousands
Writing numbers in figures and words
Expanded form using place values
Face value vs place value of a digit
Forming numbers from given digits
out_of_scope: Numbers beyond 10,000 in detail (Introduced in Class 5)
Roman numerals (not in CBSE Class 4 NCERT)

concepts.concept_name: Comparing numbers using greater than, less than, and equal to
Arranging numbers in ascending and descending order
Finding the greatest and smallest numbers from given digits
Rounding numbers to the nearest 10, 100, and 1000

in_scope: Comparing numbers up to 10,000 using < > =
Ascending order (smallest to largest)
Descending order (largest to smallest)
Forming greatest and smallest numbers from given digits
Rounding to nearest 10, 100, and 1000
Successor and predecessor of a number
out_of_scope: Rounding to nearest 10,000 or beyond (Introduced in Class 5)

concepts.concept_name: Addition of 3-digit and 4-digit numbers with carrying
Subtraction of 3-digit and 4-digit numbers with borrowing
Properties of addition (commutative, associative, identity)
Word problems involving addition and subtraction

in_scope: Addition of numbers up to 4 digits with regrouping
Subtraction of numbers up to 4 digits with borrowing
Adding and subtracting more than two numbers
Commutative property: a + b = b + a
Associative property: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c)
Additive identity: a + 0 = a
Checking subtraction using addition
Word problems with real-life Indian contexts
out_of_scope: Addition/subtraction of 5+ digit numbers (Introduced in Class 5)
Addition/subtraction of decimals (Introduced later in Class 4/5)
Addition/subtraction of fractions in this topic

concepts.concept_name: Multiplication tables up to 12
Multiplication of 2-digit by 2-digit numbers
Properties of multiplication (commutative, associative, distributive, identity, zero property)
Word problems involving multiplication

in_scope: Multiplication tables from 2 to 12
Multiplying 2-digit by 1-digit numbers
Multiplying 2-digit by 2-digit numbers
Multiplying by 10, 100
Commutative property: a x b = b x a
Associative property: (a x b) x c = a x (b x c)
Distributive property: a x (b + c) = (a x b) + (a x c)
Multiplicative identity: a x 1 = a
Zero property: a x 0 = 0
Word problems with Indian contexts

concepts.concept_name: Division of 2-digit and 3-digit numbers by a 1-digit number
Understanding remainders in division
Checking division using multiplication (Dividend = Divisor x Quotient + Remainder)
Word problems involving division

in_scope: Division of 2-digit numbers by 1-digit numbers
Division of 3-digit numbers by 1-digit numbers
Long division method
Division with and without remainders
Checking: Dividend = (Divisor x Quotient) + Remainder
Division by 10
Properties: any number divided by 1 equals itself; 0 divided by any number equals 0
Word problems with real-life contexts
out_of_scope: Division of 4+ digit numbers (Introduced in Class 5)

concepts.concept_name: Understanding multiples of a number
Understanding factors of a number
Finding all factors of a given number
Common factors of two numbers (introduction)

in_scope: Multiples: skip counting to list multiples
First 10 multiples of a given number
Every number is a multiple of 1 and itself
Factors: numbers that divide a given number exactly
Listing all factors of numbers up to 100
1 is a factor of every number
Every number is a factor of itself
Common factors of two small numbers
out_of_scope: Prime and composite numbers formally (Introduced in Class 5)
Divisibility rules beyond basic (Introduced in Class 5)

concepts.concept_name: Proper fractions and their representation
Improper fractions and mixed numbers
Converting between improper fractions and mixed numbers
Equivalent fractions
Comparing and ordering fractions

in_scope: Proper fractions: numerator < denominator
Improper fractions: numerator >= denominator
Mixed numbers: whole number + proper fraction
Converting improper fraction to mixed number and vice versa
Equivalent fractions by multiplying/dividing numerator and denominator by the same number
Comparing fractions with same denominator
Comparing fractions with same numerator
Fraction of a collection/group
out_of_scope: Comparing fractions with different numerators and denominators (cross-multiplication, Introduced in Class 5)
Fractions on number line in detail (Introduced in Class 5)
Multiplication and division of fractions (Introduced in Class 5)
Decimals and fractions interconversion in this topic

concepts.concept_name: Addition of like fractions (same denominator)
Subtraction of like fractions (same denominator)
Addition and subtraction of simple unlike fractions
Word problems on addition and subtraction of fractions

in_scope: Adding fractions with the same denominator
Subtracting fractions with the same denominator
Simple unlike fractions where one denominator is a multiple of the other
Reducing fractions to simplest form after operations
Word problems involving fraction addition and subtraction
out_of_scope: Unlike fractions with unrelated denominators requiring LCM (Introduced in Class 5)
Addition/subtraction of mixed numbers (Introduced in Class 5)

1 hour = 60 minutes, 1 minute = 60 seconds
Finding elapsed time between two given times
Reading a calendar: days in each month

concepts.concept_name: Addition and subtraction of money amounts

Making bills and calculating totals

in_scope: Indian currency: rupees and paise
1 rupee = 100 paise
Writing money in decimal form (Rs 25.50)

concepts.concept_name: Types of lines: horizontal, vertical, parallel, and perpendicular
Understanding line, ray, and line segment
Types of angles: acute, right, obtuse, and straight

in_scope: Line: extends in both directions without end
Ray: starts at a point and extends in one direction
Line segment: part of a line with two endpoints
Parallel lines: lines that never meet
Perpendicular lines: lines that meet at a right angle
Right angle = 90 degrees
Acute angle: less than 90 degrees
Obtuse angle: more than 90 degrees but less than 180 degrees
Straight angle = 180 degrees
Identifying angles in everyday objects
out_of_scope: Measuring angles with a protractor (Introduced in Class 5)
Drawing angles of specific measures (Introduced in Class 5)
Complementary and supplementary angles (Introduced in Class 5)

concepts.concept_name: Properties of 2D shapes: triangle, rectangle, square, circle
Perimeter of rectangles and squares
Perimeter of triangles and irregular shapes
Introduction to area: counting square units

in_scope: Properties of rectangle: 4 sides, 4 right angles, opposite sides equal
Properties of square: 4 equal sides, 4 right angles
Properties of triangle: 3 sides, 3 angles
Perimeter = total length of all sides
Perimeter of rectangle = 2 x (length + breadth)
Perimeter of square = 4 x side
Perimeter of triangle = sum of three sides
Area as space inside a shape
Finding area by counting square units on a grid
out_of_scope: Area formula for rectangles and squares (Introduced in Class 5)
Area of circles (Introduced in higher classes)

concepts.concept_name: Identifying common 3D shapes: cube, cuboid, sphere, cylinder, cone
Faces, edges, and vertices of 3D shapes
Relating 3D shapes to everyday objects

in_scope: Cube: 6 faces, 12 edges, 8 vertices
Cuboid: 6 faces, 12 edges, 8 vertices
Cylinder: 2 flat faces, 1 curved face, 2 edges, 0 vertices
Cone: 1 flat face, 1 curved face, 1 edge, 1 vertex
Sphere: 1 curved face, 0 edges, 0 vertices
Identifying 3D shapes in everyday objects (dice, box, ball, can, ice cream cone)
Difference between 2D and 3D shapes
out_of_scope: Surface area and volume (Introduced in higher classes)
Prisms and pyramids in detail (Introduced in Class 5)

in_scope: Patterns with constant addition (e.g., 3, 6, 9, 12, ...)

Patterns with constant multiplication (e.g., 2, 4, 8, 16, ...)

out_of_scope: Algebraic expressions for patterns (Introduced in Class 5)
